bioghist.p: Thomas Guthrie Speers (b. 1890) graduated from Princeton University in 1912 and was ordained after three years at Union Seminary and one year touring mission stations in the Far East. He served in the Army as a chaplain in the First World War. Speers was pastor of the Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church of Baltimore, Maryland, from 1928 to 1957. Speers began an outreach program to Baltimore's Jewish community, occasionally exchanging pulpits with local rabbis. He also abolished racial segregation at the church and supported the installation of the church's pipe organ by Ernest M. Skinner in 1931.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Thomas Guthrie Speers. Materials include: typed and manuscript sermons, 1920s-1983, often with date and location noted; class materials from courses on the Bible and race relations at Gilman, including exam questions, informational booklets on race relations; and notes, pamphlets, articles and reprints, and a small amount of correspondence on such topics as funerals, children's services, race relations, alcohol, bible study, US military, and trips. There is a small collection of letters to Speers from servicemen in the early 1950s and photos of Speers and family members, including his father.
